column5: I was satisfied with my overall experience at the retreat.
column6: The facilitation of the seminars and/or presentations was effective.
column7: There was adequate opportunity to connect with my INP Faculty Members and Senior Fellows.
column8: There was an appropriate balance between learning and social time.
column9: The excursions into the city and region were important to my overall retreat experience.
column10: The in-person learning environment enhanced my engagement with the retreat content.
column11: The in-person learning environment allowed me to build stronger relationships with my peers.
column12: I believe the retreat was a good use of my time.
column13: I deepened my connections with other BLI participants.
column14: As a result of the Black Futures Retreat, I feel more energized to continue doing this work.
column15: The guidance for registering for the retreat was clear and concise.
column16: The travel process (i.e., booking flights, hotel, and local travel) was simple and accessible.
column17: On site, INP staff members were accessible and responsive to my individual and full group needs
column18: The venue(s) and facilities were satisfactory for the retreat.
column19: The retreat was hosted in a way that supported my full participation (dietary needs, accessibility, materials, technology, location, accommodations, etc.)
column20: The theme and design of the Black Futures retreat resonated with me and provided a meaningful connection when reflecting on the Black Histories (Montgomery, AL) retreat that began my fellowship experience.
column21: I found the program activities engaging and relevant.
column22: The program activities addressed some of my leadership challenges and/or needs.
column23: I gained new learnings or insights at the Black Futures Retreat that I can apply to my work
column24: I built stronger relationships with other BLI fellows and faculty as a result of the retreat.
column25: Wednesday's Anacostia Bus Tour and visit to Frederick Douglass House deepened my historical knowledge and created a good opportunity for reflection.
column26: The panel conversation on Wednesday with Ruth LaToison Ifill, Andre Perry, Tonia Wellons, and Kenyan McDuffie increased my understanding of critical issues and systemic inequities in Washington, DC on community leadership
column27: Trista Harris' presentation on Thursday increased my knowledge on Futurism and ability to apply Futurism to my work as a leader.
column28: The panel conversation on Thursday with Trista Harris, Dr. Akilah Watkins, and Joe Briggs deepened my understanding of Futurism from multiple perspectives and gave me a chance to apply it to different aspects of my work.
column29: The Thursday afternoon session on policy and legislation has positively influenced my approach to policy and advocacy strategy in the post election context.
